issues.description: Constructor parameter mismatch: The problem statement and the provided template Main show animals being constructed with a single String parameter (e.g., Seal("Clarabelle")), and the UML/description only requires a name attribute to be initialized. However, the solution implementation declares constructors that require two parameters (String name, int age) for Animal and for all concrete animals (Seal, Pig, Goat). This mismatch will confuse students about the required constructor signature and will prevent them from using the example code in Main or following the UML (which implies a single name attribute).
issues.suggested_fix: Align constructor signatures across artifacts. Either (A) update the solution to provide single-argument constructors matching the problem/template (e.g., Seal(String name), Pig(String name), Goat(String name)) and remove the extra age parameter, or (B) update the problem statement and template (including example Main) to document and use the two-parameter constructors and the additional 'age' attribute. Prefer option (A) if the exercise is intended to teach only the name attribute as shown in the UML and example Main.

issues.description: Attribute mismatch: The UML and problem description specify that Animal has a name attribute (String name) and require constructors to initialize class attributes; there is no mention of an age attribute. The solution's Animal class adds an int age field (with getter/setter) and initializes it via the constructor. This introduces an extra class attribute not present in the problem statement/UML/template and changes what "all class attributes" means for students.
issues.suggested_fix: Remove the additional 'age' attribute from the solution's Animal class (and corresponding getters/setters and constructor parameter) so the solution matches the UML/problem (Animal with only a name). Alternatively, explicitly add 'age' to the problem statement UML and update the template Main example to construct animals with a name and age, so all artifacts consistently document the attribute.
